145.text:

When I’m in the hearing world it can be

234.text:

239.text:

248.text:

so I decided that when I came to Wellington

628.text:
I was lucky growing up to have a deaf brother
so we could actually support each other.

633.text:
We were bouncing ideas off each other and we
didn’t feel alone so that was great,

639.text:
Our family are really supportive but beyond
that I went to a mainstream school

643.text:
and I was one deaf person in amongst a full
class of hearing students.

647.text:
When the teacher spoke at the front of the class
I didn’t understand any of it, for the whole day

653.text:
so it was really hard to follow and I focused
mostly on reading from books

657.text: and also copying from people next to me

662.text:
so a lot of the time at school I didn’t really
understand the topics. But then when I got

669.text:
home my parents would sit down with me and
ask what I did and I’d show them the book,

674.text:
then they would explain it, they would repeat
it to both of us and it was easier for us

680.text:
to lip read within the family because we knew
each other well. So really a lot of my education

687.text:
was from my parents and as we grew up my brother
became my tutor as well so that family support

693.text:
was paramount. At that time they had special
education services to support deaf children

699.text:
in the schools but I received very little
to no support.

Mark when you’re in the hearing world, what

When I Christchurch I felt like I had to be

728.text:

being funny. And so, humour was a way of getting

736.text:

744.text:
into a party things begin quietly – but
if I can entertain then people see me as more

749.text:
approachable. Now I feel like I can be myself
more when I’m being funny,

758.text: or perhaps it’s just that I’m funny looking!

I think for members of the public who have
never really seen sign language or who have

824.text:
never really encountered it, a lot of people
don’t realise that sign language is actually

830.text:
a full complete language. There’s an assumption
that it’s dumbed down… or it’s a more simple

837.text:
language certainly inferior to English or French

In some ways my kids who
are hearing benefit…they have developed

882.text:
the understanding that their parents are different

943.text:
sign language. There are night classes that
they can go to but those night classes focus

949.text:

958.text:
which isn’t the vocabulary you need to be
talking with your children. We’ve produced

963.text:
a DVD to teach people how to communicate with
children of this age.

1004.text:

1010.text:

1016.text:
That’s really hard. There is also no funding

1022.text:
parent interviews, which is a real concern

1026.text:
at school so that I can then encourage and

1068.text:
I feel like I can’t be involved even though

1072.text:
around all those school things that I mentioned
before. I feel really excluded…second class.

1079.text:
And that certainly frustrates me. It’s sad,
I’m used to this after years of similar

1085.text:
circumstances growing up as a Deaf person,
the obstacles have always been there. But

1090.text:
now it’s different because those obstacles

1096.text:
Because my children see that their mum can’t

even more sad that my children have to see

pretty much stopped doing that and it feels

What’s it like for you Mark are there sometimes

Sometimes I can’t be involved in groups

I’m really keen to be involved. I have lots

So how does that make you feel when you’re

1206.text:
When I’m not included it makes me feel a

1210.text:
I know I could do these things and enjoy doing

1215.text:

1226.text:

me they’d realise that isn’t the case
and that Deaf people have impressive ideas

1240.text:
The late 1880’s British immigrants brought
sign language to New Zealand. But for nearly

1243.text:
one hundred years educators banned children
from using sign language

1250.text:
So began a period of oral education where
children were taught to lipread

1254.text: made to speak even forced to sit on their hands.

1257.text:
But children and adults continued to use sign
language it survived underground

1261.text:
in places like deaf club and developed into the
unique and indigenous language it is today.

1271.text:
There’s a lot more information and description
and documentation about sign language now

1278.text:
so hearing people can actually learn the language
and they can be more aware of it. Deaf people

1284.text:
have got a stronger sense of pride and feeling
they can share the language with other people.

1294.text:
So now with the younger generations they regard
it as a language and as a natural thing to

1300.text:
be doing and i think society sees deaf people
signing and is more recognising of what that

1306.text:
is that it's a language and it belongs to
a community.

1311.text:
Could you explain to me how important New
Zealand sign language is and how it’s linked

1315.text:
to Deaf culture and why the languge is so
important.

1318.text:
The language is the heart of the culture,
without the fact that deaf people use

1322.text:
Sign Language with each other they wouldn’t
be a community and so the language, first of

1327.text:
all, is the thing that brings them together
and bonds them as a community and it’s also

1331.text:
the medium through which they pass on knowledge
to each other and traditions and stories and

1337.text: all the things that are part of the culture.

1339.text:
What do you think are some of the frustrations
for Deaf people?

1346.text:
There are still many barriers experienced
by the Deaf community, areas that they can’t

1355.text:
access. One of the most important things is
that Deaf children have education. Sure, I

1362.text:
completed my education, but deaf children
there are the future of the deaf community.

1366.text:
For some people it might seem strange, but
we feel like a big whanau and we really need

1373.text:
to improve education for the deaf youth of
today to become community members in the future.

1382.text:
There’s a huge barrier to edcuation, if
there’s access to edcuation then we don’t

1387.text:
need those other people lobbying for us later
on, we can lobby for oursevles, we can be

1394.text:
more proactive, so education and access to
the cirriculum in sign language are key.

1406.text:
So what do you reckon Mark, I mean there’s
definitely been some improvements,

1410.text: but what do you think needs to change?

1412.text:
We need more funding for interpreters because
I feel like I’ve got plenty I could contribute

1416.text:
to society but I can’t because of the language
barriers so it’s dissapointing.

1450.text:
Without subtitles, interpreters, etc, there’s
a lot of mainstream culture, everyday life,

1457.text:
that deaf people miss out on and end up feeling
isolated. You could compare it to a foreigner

1461.text:
coming to this country but of course they
could soon learn English and get involved

1467.text: and do what they want when they want.

1475.text:
Everyone has the right to communicate, it’s
not a privilege to communicate, it is a right

1481.text:
and so therefore it’s not just about deaf
people communicating with other deaf people

1486.text:
- it’s about all people being able to communicate
in all different languages.

1496.text:
I still don’t think we’ve really got our
message through about sign language. I don’t

1503.text:
think New Zealand is really committed to encouraging

1509.text:
Sign language is part of New Zealand society
and we are all part of that society

1519.text:
I grew up in New Zealand having been born

1525.text:

don’t think I’m alone in that. I think

1530.text:
a lot of other deaf people don’t know the

It’s been fascinating - there’s lots of
